channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: May 12
item.description: A roundup of local election-related news for Monday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: India Ink: A Second Conversation With: Times Now Editor Arnab Goswami
item.description: India Ink follows up with the television journalist, known for his aggressive interviews, after his one-on-one with Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The ‘Coming Home’ of Zhang Yimou and Gong Li
item.description: In “Coming Home,” Zhang Yimou examines China’s troubled political past and suggests how to deal with it today. With his legendary muse, Gong Li, playing the central character, the film represents a return to form for the director.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Chen Daoming as Lu Yanshi, who returns home after 20 years in prison in Zhang Yimou's "Coming Home."

item.title: Vietnam Fails to Rally Partners in China Dispute
item.description: Asean members declined to point fingers at the region’s top trade partner, while in Vietnam there are also divisions over how to handle China’s forceful maritime assertiveness.
item.dc:creator: By MIKE IVES and THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Protesters shouted anti-China slogans during a rally in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Sunday in reaction to a territorial tussle in the South China Sea.

item.title: A Push to Aid American Couple Held in Child’s Death in Qatar
item.description: A YouTube video was posted to raise money for the defense of the Huangs of Los Angeles, whose adopted daughter — known to go on hunger strikes — died after four days of not eating.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grace and Matthew Huang of Los Angeles in Doha, Qatar, in March. A YouTube video seeks to raise money for their defense.

item.title: Trying to Salvage Remains of Blackwater Case
item.description: The case, in which five security guards were indicted on manslaughter and weapons charges, once seemed clear-cut. But it has been repeatedly undermined by the government’s own mistakes.
item.dc:creator: By MATT APUZZO
item.media:description: An Iraqi traffic police officer in 2007 with a car destroyed by a Blackwater security detail in a shooting that left 17 people dead.

item.title: Russia Revisits Its History to Nail Down Its Future
item.description: Russia’s national obsession with fascism is playing down the darker aspects of Soviet history and obliterating objective debate over current foreign policy issues, critics say.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: The Victory Day Parade in Red Square on Friday commemorated the 1945 defeat of Nazi Germany, the apex of the Soviet Union’s showdown with Western power.

item.title: Ukraine Vote on Separation Held in Chaos
item.description: Separatists in Donetsk and Slovyansk cast early ballots in support of local autonomy, but the U.S. and Europe condemned the vote and said they would not recognize the results.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: In Town of Missing Girls, Sorrow, but Little Progress
item.description: In Chibok, where as many as 276 girls were taken by Boko Haram militants, a deep frustration at the lack of progress made in the search has settled in.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Mothers of the missing schoolgirls wailed in anguish on Sunday as they waited for a visiting dignitary in the burned-out ruins of the Government Girls Secondary School in Chibok.

item.title: Venice Journal: Island Fixer-Upper, Near the Madding Crowd
item.description: Fearing that Poveglia, an island for sale in the Venetian Lagoon, could be developed into a luxury resort for rich visitors, a group of Venetians is proposing that the island should instead be a refuge from the onslaught of tourists.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Marco Di Lauro for The New York Times
item.media:description: An abandoned hospital on Poveglia Island. The Italian government wants to sell the island; Venetians fear development.

item.title: Europe-Bound Migrants Killed When Boat Capsizes Off Libya
item.description: Dozens of people were dead or missing, according to officials in Libya, which has become a transit point for tens of thousands of Africans headed for Europe in rickety, crowded boats.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: European Candidates See Opportunity on Extreme Edge
item.description: Parties outside the mainstream are expected to win as many as a quarter of the 750 seats in the European Parliament, as far-right leaders portray the European Union as a gateway for illegal immigrants and a threat to national sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Michal Novotny for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adam B. Bartos, a Czech journalist a Czech who is running in May elections for the European Parliament, is invoking an anti-Semitic appeal in his campaign.

item.title: A Devotion to Language Proves Risky
item.description: Last August, three men were arrested and accused of “illegal fund-raising,” charges that stemmed from their effort to finance a Uighur-language school in Xinjiang, China.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Abduweli Ayup, an American-educated linguist from China’s Xinjiang region, has not been heard from since his arrest.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Show Us the Drone Memos
item.description: We must see the legal case for executing a United States citizen without a trial.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By RAND PAUL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Party Chief’s Downfall a Central Act in Tiananmen Drama
item.description: Zhao Ziyang, the embattled Communist Party general secretary, appeared to have misread treacherous political currents and was outmaneuvered by Deng Xiaoping.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Retro Report: Agent Orange’s Long Legacy, for Vietnam and Veterans
item.description: More than 40 years after the American military used Agent Orange in the Vietnam War, the chemical still casts a long shadow over the Vietnamese and the American veterans who fought there.
item.dc:creator: By CLYDE HABERMAN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Forget Facebook, Bring Back Samizdat
item.description: If Putin blocks the Internet, Russian activists should revive Soviet dissidents’ methods.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By GAL BECKERMAN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: India's Nuclear Imposture
item.description: No political group has the wherewithal to fix the dangerous ambiguities of India's defense policy.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By ABHIJIT IYER-MITRA

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Follow the Money, China-Style
item.description: The economy's mystery of surplus currency yet low inflation may be a result of the piles of cash hoarded by corrupt officials.
item.dc:creator: By YU HUA

item.title: Samsung Leader Stable After Heart Attack
item.description: Lee Kun-hee, 72, has previously been treated for lung cancer and pneumonia, and his latest health problem will almost certainly renew calls for a concrete succession plan.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT and BRIAN X. CHEN

item.title: Basics: The Social Life of Spiders Thriving in a Social Web
item.description: Most spiders are loners, but social spiders live in groups, and a new study suggests that their predictable social lives accentuate individual quirks and personal styles.
item.dc:creator: By NATALIE ANGIER

item.title: 20 Iraqi Soldiers Are Killed in Barracks Attack
item.description: The troops had been in charge of protecting a pipeline in the north that sends crude oil to international markets.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Protest of Planned Incinerator Turns Violent in Chinese City
item.description: At least 10 demonstrators and 29 police officers were injured on Saturday in one of eastern China’s biggest cities.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: Front-Runner in Afghan Election Secures a Key Ally
item.description: The presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah won the endorsement of the third-place candidate, Zalmay Rassoul, for the runoff vote next month.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: First Lady Condemns Abduction of Nigerian Schoolgirls
item.description: Michelle Obama said that she and President Obama had been personally touched by the abduction of Nigerian schoolgirls by terrorists, calling it an “unconscionable” act.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: Michelle Obama spoke about Mother’s Day in the weekly radio address that is normally delivered by her husband.
